text: 1. The mists gather, that is the hiṅkâra; the cloud has risen, that is the prastâva; it rains, that is the udgîtha; it flashes and thunders, that is the pratihâra; it stops, that is the nidhana. That is the Vairûpa Sâman, as interwoven in Par g anya, the god of rain.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Khândogya Upanishad... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. He who thus knows the Vairûpa as interwoven in Par g anya, obtains all kinds of cattle (virûpa), he reaches the full life, he lives long, becomes great with children and cattle, great by fame. His rule is, 'Never complain of the rain.'
